title: Next Link in potential $2.5 billion initial public offering
text:
Link Group is having a run at the ASX boards. by Sarah Thompson Anthony Macdonald Jake Mitchell Link Group, which is on track to be the biggest float of year, will kick off its analyst roadshow next week ahead of a potential $1 billion raising.
As revealed by Street Talk Online , Link's joint lead managers, Deutsche Bank, Citi, Macquarie Capital and UBS, have started booking in meetings with fund managers based domestically and abroad.
The analyst roadshow marks the more formal stage of the IPO process after Link, majority-owned by private equity firm Pacific Equity Partners and worth around $2.5 billion, conducted early-stage investor briefings in June.
It's understood the company will be compared to share registry Computershare, accounting software group MYOB and financial software operator IRESS.
But the deal team is expected to argue Link's business and growth outlook is more like Nasdaq-listed "fintech" company SS&C Technologies Holdings than anything in Australia, as revealed by Street Talk.
The JLM's will split up and cover Australia, New Zealand, Asia, the United Kingdom and the United States.
The roadshow is significant not just because of Link's size but because it's a vote of confidence in the IPO market following a bout of extreme sharemarket volatility.
Equity capital markets bankers watching the benchmark S&P/ASX briefly slump below 5000 points this week would have feared the IPO window may have slammed shut.
 But that doesn't appear to be the case, at least for larger, quality companies like Link.
The super fund administrator, share register, and data management company is one of PEP's oldest investments.
The planned divestment comes after Street Talk revealed PEP had closed its fifth fund at just over $2.1 billion on Friday. The raising was achieved via a series of rolling closures after PEP reached its first close of $1.1 billion last year.
Link is expected to post an underlying EBITDA of $180 million this financial year, up from $150 million last year.
Elsewhere, brokers were pitching to sell down part of TPG and The Carlyle Group's $1.7 billion stake in private hospital operator Healthscope on Wednesday night.
Goldman Sachs, Macquarie Capital and UBS were understood to be fighting it out for the mandate to sell just over 300 million shares, or about half TPG and Carlyle's stake.
Finally, as revealed by Street Talk Online , Wilson HTM sold a line of 2.3 million shares in Bellamy's Australia, worth around $15 million.
The floor price was set at $6.40 a share and the deal was done at $6.70. Bellamy's closed at $6.91 on Wednesday.
Bellamy's chairman Robert Woolley, managing director Laura McBain and other management are selling down stock.
